intro: Plagiogyria communis, commonly known as the common plagiogyria, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It typically grows to a height of 20–50 cm, featuring lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers in clusters, usually greenish-white in color, which develop into capsule fruits containing numerous tiny seeds. Plagiogyria communis thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or streamside habitats. Its botanical characteristics make it a valuable species for ecological studies and wetland restoration projects.
